Installation

It is strongly recommended to install and use conda for environment management, as some of MGSurvE’s dependencies might clash with specific packages versions. These installation instructions assume conda is already installed in the target system.

Uneventful (tested on Linux)

Create a clean python=3.10 environment:

conda create -n MGSurvE python="3.10" -y

Activate the environment, and install MGSurvE using pip:

conda activate MGSurvE
pip install MGSurvE

If this ran correctly, try importing the package from the terminal with:

python
import MGSurvE as srv

If cartopy is not currently installed, we will get a warning that we can safely ignore unless we are planning to work with realistic geo-spatial landscapes. In case we are interested in such projects, we can run:

conda install -c conda-forge cartopy

If any of these steps resulted in an error, have a look at the next section in this installation guide.

Dependency Errors (sometimes happens on MacOS)

Sometimes, either DEAP, libpysal, or cartopy decide not to play nicely. For these cases, the following procedure might help.

In a fresh environment on python=3.10 (or one in which the installation of MGSurvE failed), run the following commands to install DEAP and libpysal (both of which are required for MGSurvE to work):

conda install -c conda-forge deap -y
conda install -c conda-forge libpysal -y

With these packages installed, we can proceed and install MGSurvE:

pip install MGSurvE

which should be enough to get us started.

Finally, if we are interested in the map-plotting routines, we will need cartopy installed. The easiest way to install the dependency is through anaconda:

conda install cartopy -y

If this installation fails, or if import MGSurvE fails on python due to errors in the dependency, we might need to have a look at their documentation for more information.
